title.term: \nth[(i,j)] minor of a square matrix A

li.p: the determinant of the smaller square matrix obtained from A by removing the \nth[i] row and the \nth[j] column

title.term: \nth[(i,j)] cofactor of a square matrix A

li.p: equal to either the corresponding minor of A or its negative, depending on whether i+j is even or odd

title.term: cofactor expansion along the \nth[i] row of square matrix A

li.p: the formula a_{i1}C_{i1}+a_{i2}C_{i2}+\dotsb+a_{in}C_{in}, where C_{ij} denotes the \nth[(i,j)] cofactor of A

title.term: cofactor expansion along the \nth[j] column of square matrix A

li.p: the formula a_{1j}C_{1j}+a_{2j}C_{2j}+\dotsb+a_{nj}C_{nj}, where again C_{ij} denotes the \nth[(i,j)] cofactor of A

title.term: determinant of a square matrix A

li.p: the common value of all cofactor expansions of A

paragraphs.title: Alternate determinant notation
paragraphs.p:
When computing cofactor expansions, we are often performing determinant calculations inside determinant calculations, and it becomes awkward to have \det symbols littered throughout our intermediate calculations. So we will also write \abs{A} to mean the determinant of a matrix, especially for actual matrices. For example,
A \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 3\\4 \amp 5 \amp 6\\7 \amp 8 \amp 9 \end{bmatrix} \amp \amp \implies \amp \det A \amp = \begin{vmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 3\\4 \amp 5 \amp 6\\7 \amp 8 \amp 9 \end{vmatrix}.
